topic: Provide a report on the circumstances surrounding the arrest and detention of former Malaysian deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim in September 1998. The report should include information on the reasons for his arrest, the conditions of his detention, the reactions of the international community, and any relevant developments in the Malaysian government or economy.
questions: What was the event that marked the beginning of the end of Mahathir Mohamad's 17-year rule as the Prime Minister of Malaysia?
Who was Anwar Ibrahim and what was his role in the Malaysian government before his arrest?
What was the reason for Anwar Ibrahim's arrest, according to Mahathir Mohamad?
How did Anwar Ibrahim's supporters use the internet to respond to his arrest?
What was the international community's reaction to Anwar Ibrahim's arrest and alleged abuse in custody?
What was the economic situation in Malaysia during Mahathir Mohamad's 17-year rule?
How did Mahathir Mohamad's government respond to the street demonstrations and protests following Anwar Ibrahim's arrest?
What was the impact of Anwar Ibrahim's arrest on Malaysia's international relations and economy?
Who were some of the regional leaders who considered boycotting the Malaysian meeting in response to Anwar Ibrahim's arrest?

What were the charges brought against Anwar Ibrahim and his friend?

What was the name of the summit that was to be held in Malaysia, which was affected by the political crisis?
How did Mahathir Mohamad's reversal of his economic policy in September 1998 affect his relationship with Anwar Ibrahim?
report: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad ruled adroitly for 17 years until September 1998 when he suddenly reversed his economic policy and fired his popular deputy and heir apparent, Anwar Ibrahim. Anwar organized a political opposition leading Mahathir to arrest him. Mahathir met street demonsrations with tear gas and water cannon, but his censorship did not reach Anwar's internet support. News that police had beaten Anwar brutally brought protests from around the world, but the Malaysian trade minister discounted any unrest. Anwar remained in custody as lawyers appealed. Malaysia hardly provided a salubrious setting for the forthcoming economic summit. Mahathir's 17-year rule saw great advances. Now, Malaysia has economic crisis and instability. Photos show bruised Anwar, who says police beat him. Mahathir requests investigation. Anwar supporters use internet to air views, photos, speeches. EU is concerned about reports of his abuse and hopes for appropriate actions. Habibie and Estrada may stay away from APEC talks over Anwar's arrest. A witness against Anwar asks for appeal of his conviction. Anwar says false confession was coerced. Lawyers demand Anwar's release. Ruling party leaders discuss Anwar's replacement; Mahathir not choosy. Rafidah says arrest won't cause unrest or scare away investors. Newspaper photos of the bruised face of Thailand's jailed former deputy minister, Anwar Ibrahim, has aroused international condemnation as well as local demonstrations. Ibrahim, considered heir-apparent to Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamed, was fired by Mahathir for being morally unfit for office. Anwar mounted a nationwide campaign against Mahathir before his arrest. Mahathir served as Prime Minister for 17 years with a bold socio-economic program that had veered into recession. Anwar differed with Mahathir over economic policy and began speaking out against him. Mahathir has not selected a successor and if he resigns or dies, a power struggle could ensue. Malaysian PM Mahathir Mohamad fired Deputy PM Anwar Ibrahim, once groomed as a successor but now called unfit to lead and trying to topple him, after an economic disagreement. Anwar and a friend were charged with illegal homosexual activity. Anwar showed marks of a beating during 10 days in custody. The EU condemned his abuse and regional leaders considered boycotting a Malaysian meeting. Anwar's treatment sparked street riots and protests on the Internet. Lawyers demanded his release. The incident damaged Mahathir's 17-years of good leadership and isolated Malaysia from international markets, although the Malaysian trade minister played down its effect.
response:
The arrest and detention of former Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim in September 1998 were a pivotal moment in Malaysian politics. Anwar's detention was sparked by his disagreement with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad on economic policy, which led to his dismissal on September 2. Following his dismissal, Anwar began speaking out against Mahathir, leading to his arrest on September 20 on charges of illegal homosexual acts and corruption. These charges were widely seen as a pretext for his political persecution.

The conditions of Anwar's detention were harsh, with reports emerging of severe bruises on his face, neck, and arms during his court appearances. Initially, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad suggested that Anwar had inflicted the injuries on himself, but he has since called for a full investigation into the matter. The international community was quick to react, with Indonesian President B.J. Habibie expressing concerns about attending the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Malaysia due to the perceived mistreatment of Anwar.

The arrest of Anwar had significant implications for the Malaysian government and economy. Trade Minister Rafidah Aziz stated that the arrest would not lead to significant social unrest or deter investors. However, the incident has tarnished the image of the Malaysian police, with calls for a full investigation into the matter. The arrest also highlighted the authoritarian tendencies of the Malaysian government, with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's government being criticized for its human rights record.

In conclusion, the arrest and detention of Anwar Ibrahim in September 1998 were a significant event in Malaysian politics, marked by controversy and outrage. The incident highlighted the authoritarian tendencies of the Malaysian government and the need for greater transparency and accountability in the country's institutions. As noted by Trade Minister Rafidah Aziz, the arrest of one individual should not cause unrest, but the incident has had far-reaching consequences for the country's image and reputation.  .

topic: Write a report that describes the 1998 federal budget negotiations, the issues that delayed the negotiations, and the eventual agreement that was reached.
questions: What were some of the issues that delayed budget negotiations between the White House and House Republicans?
What was the uncertain future of the contraceptive issue in the budget negotiations?
What was the disagreement between the parties regarding education funding?
What was unusual about the 1998 federal budget negotiations?
What were the three main options for using the surplus in the budget negotiations?
What were some of the major issues in the budget negotiations?
How did the committees craft the budget document?
What were some of the most difficult issues to resolve in the budget negotiations?
How did conservatives feel about the results of the budget negotiations?
What was included in the omnibus spending package?
How would the new spending be offset in the budget?
What was the challenge of reaching agreement in the budget negotiations without a common goal of reducing the deficit?
What policy provisions were tied to the spending package and hotly debated?
report: Budget negotiations between the White House and House Republicans were delayed on several issues. At issue were provisions that included requiring Federal Health Insurance providers to provide contraceptives to women as Well as a provision to build a road across a wildlife preserve in Alaska. The contraceptive issue faced an uncertain future while Clinton likely will veto the road. There is disagreement also on how to spend the funding on education. This year's budget discussions also have been hampered because it is the first time since budget procedures were established in 1974 that there has been a surplus, preventing agreement on a budget resolution. Whether to use the 1st surplus in decades for a tax cut, to pay off the national debt, or for new initiatives made the 1998 federal budget negotiations chaotic. The Oct 1 start of the fiscal year was extended 5 times. Major issues were census statistical sampling, federal health plan coverage of contraceptives regardless of religious affiliation, and school aid decisions by the federal gov't or local jurisdictions. Other issues included a Federal Election Commission provision, a road through an Alaskan wildlife refuge, and an airline peanut ban. Committees crafted the budget document after broad agreement was reached when 8 bills were lumped together. In 1998, for the first time in decades, the US budget negotiators faced a surplus. Both sides said this was harder than a deficit situation, but they finally spent $1.7 trillion. The last seven spending bills were the most difficult and finally were merged into one package. Controversial issues included health insurance paying for contraception, control of new education allocations, an Alaskan wilderness road, whether the 2000 census would include statistical sampling, and establishing an emergency fund. Conservatives felt the results favored the liberals, but both sides were satisfied and glad to finish before Election Day and avoid a government shutdown. After several deadline extensions, Congressional leaders and the White House agreed on an omnibus spending package, the final portion of the $1.7 trillion budget. It includes more money for education and defense, business tax breaks, and farm aid, as well as funds for Colombia to use in drug interdiction. To offset the new spending, the surplus will be tapped for $20 billion, to the ire of conservatives. This year, without the common goal of reducing the deficit, reaching agreement was very difficult. Policy provisions involving the 2000 census, contraception, and the Alaskan wilderness were also tied to the spending package and were hotly debated.
response:
The 1998 federal budget negotiations were a challenging and complex process that was marked by significant delays and disagreements between Congressional Republicans and the White House. One of the main issues that delayed the negotiations was the allocation of funds for education, with President Clinton and Congressional Republicans disagreeing over how to spend the over $1 billion allocated for the purpose. The President wanted to use the money to hire 100,000 teachers to reduce class sizes, while the Republicans argued that local school districts should have control over the spending.

In addition to the education issue, the negotiations were also delayed by disagreements over specific provisions, such as the creation of "peanut-free" zones on airlines. This proposal, along with other provisions, was included in a $500 billion package that was hailed by President Clinton and Republican leaders, but was criticized by conservatives who expressed concerns over the $20 billion taken from the surplus to address emergencies. The conservatives also cited concerns over the lack of a serious tax cut, but were expected to vote in favor of the package due to its increase in defense spending and aid to farmers.

Despite the delays and disagreements, the negotiations eventually reached an agreement that was expected to exceed 3,000 pages. The agreement included a number of provisions, such as the extension of tax breaks for Individual Retirement Accounts to couples with incomes from $100,000 to $150,000, which would actually raise a small amount of revenue in the next five years but make the picture considerably worse in later years. The agreement also included the designation of $20 billion as "emergency" expenditures, which would use up more than one-quarter of the anticipated budget surplus in the current fiscal year.

The agreement was not without controversy, however, with conservative Republicans expressing concerns over specific issues, such as the requirement for federal health plans to cover contraceptives and the prohibition on overseas family-planning organizations from lobbying to change abortion laws in other countries. Rep. Tom Coburn, R-Okla., sought to modify the health plan measure to allow plans to refuse contraceptive coverage on moral grounds, and to eliminate two types of contraception that he believed interfered with fertilization. Democrats, such as Rep. Nita Lowey, D-N.Y., strongly objected to Coburn's position, arguing that health plans make decisions based on profits, not morals. Overall, the 1998 federal budget negotiations were a complex and challenging process that was marked by significant delays and disagreements, but ultimately resulted in an agreement that was expected to exceed 3,000 pages. topic: Summarize the activities and the results of President Clinton's visit to Israel, Gaza and the West Bank in December 1998, within the context of the Wye River accord. Include information on the reactions of Hamas, Israel and Palestine to the visit, and the impact of the visit on the peace process and the political positions of President Clinton and Prime Minister Netanyahu.
questions: Where will President Clinton visit from December 12-15?
What did Hamas say about Clinton's trip to the region?
What is Netanyahu's opinion on Arafat's handling of the Wye accord?
What are some of the concerns of the Israelis and Palestinians during this time?
What is the extra security in place for during Clinton's visit?
What is one of the key issues of disagreement between Israel and Palestine?
What is the status of Israeli troop withdrawal from the West Bank?
What are the Palestinian leaders' actions regarding the 1964 Israeli destruction clause?
What are the conditions set by Israel for withdrawing West Bank troops?
What is Palestine's claim regarding Israel's compliance with the Accord?
How does the radical Islam group Hamas view Clinton's visit and the Accord?
What is one of the reasons Clinton's leadership is threatened?
What are some of the problems that immediately faced the Wye agreement?
Why did Netanyahu finally refuse to move the peace process forward?
report: Clinton will visit Israel, Gaza and the West bank Dec. 12-15 as agreed in the Wye River accord. The days preceding his trip are filled with violence, unrest and divisiveness. Hamas denounces Clinton's trip, but makes no threats against him. Netanyahu says Arafat is "making a farce" of the Wye accord. The two sides disagree over its terms. The Israelis and Palestinians are troubled by violence, fear and loss. Clinton has impeachment troubles. Extra security is in place wherever Clinton will go. He hopes to salvage the Wye accord. However, Netanyahu continues to withdraw troops from the West Bank as stipulated in the agreement. Despite concerns it might cause more unrest, President Clinton met in Israel separately with Prime Minister Netanyahu and Yasser Arafat to negotiate Wye Accord agreement terms. Israel is demanding revocation of anti-Israeli clauses in the 1964 Palestinian charter. Palestine is demanding Israel's release of Palestinian prisoners. Both sides are exchanging accusations over Israeli West Bank settlements and anti-Israeli violence. Hamas denounced Clinton's visit but avoided threats. US and Palestinian agents kept the Gaza area secure. In the end, Netanyahu, facing political turmoil, told President Clinton he would not remove his troops from the West Bank. Security high for Clinton's visit to Gaza, part of the Wye Accord, as Palestinian leaders revoke a 1964 Israeli destruction clause. Israel claims Air Force One landing in Palestinian is sovereign recognition. It won't withdraw West Bank troops unless Palestinians formally vote to revoke the clause and violence stops. Palestine says Israel violated the Accord by improper prisoner releases, roadbuilding and settlement expansion. It warns of violence and there have been stone-throwing protests. Radical Islam group Hamas denounces the visit and the Accord. Clinton has made ending the long feud a crusade. Both Clinton and Netanyahu's leadership threatened. Clinton traveled to the mid-East in December in an effort to energize the Wye agreement signed by Israel and Palestine. Problems immediately faced this accord, intended to trade Israeli territory for security. Questions remained on which prisoners should be released and what constituted a vote to revoke a 1964 call to destroy Israel. Jewish settlers continued to take more lands. Violence and demonstrations went on. The Israeli far right was angry. Clinton was facing impeachment hearings. History and hatred were too strong for him to succeed. Netanyahu finally refused to move the peace process forward, but probably still will be voted out of office.
response:
In December 1998, President Clinton visited Israel, Gaza, and the West Bank as part of the Wye River accord. The visit was a significant step in the peace process, which aimed to reduce tensions and promote dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians. However, the visit was also met with skepticism by some, including Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu, who accused Yasser Arafat of making a "farce" of the Wye River accords. Netanyahu expressed concerns that the Palestinians were emboldened to foment street riots and threaten to declare statehood because they believed they had the Clinton administration "in their back pocket." This sentiment was echoed by Hamas, which denounced Clinton's visit to the Gaza Strip, although it carefully avoided making any direct threats against the President. The group's restraint likely reflects its desire to maintain a level of restraint in its public statements.

In preparation for the visit, armored personnel carriers were deployed around the convention center where Clinton would address 1,500 Palestinian delegates. The Palestinian police chief, Ghazi Jabali, stated that there was cooperation between the American security people and the Palestinians, each having their own plan and procedures in place. The visit was also seen as an opportunity for Clinton to address Palestinian leaders and formally revoke anti-Israel clauses in the 1964 Palestinian charter. This move was in line with Israel's demands, which had been made during U.S.-brokered negotiations last month. The issue of prisoner releases remained a contentious point, with Netanyahu maintaining that Israel never promised to release those with "blood on their hands," and Arafat claiming that Netanyahu had agreed to free 750 Palestinians jailed for anti-Israel attacks.

The impact of the visit on the peace process was significant, with Clinton's efforts to promote dialogue and reduce tensions seen as a crucial step towards a peaceful resolution. However, the visit also highlighted the challenges facing the peace process, including the issue of prisoner releases and the Palestinian demand for sovereignty. Netanyahu's refusal to agree to further troop withdrawals until a halt to anti-Israel violence also created tension, with Clinton facing criticism for not doing enough to lower Palestinian expectations. Ultimately, the visit marked a significant moment in the peace process, but it also highlighted the complexities and challenges that remained to be addressed.

The visit also had implications for the political positions of President Clinton and Prime Minister Netanyahu. Clinton's efforts to promote dialogue and reduce tensions were seen as a key aspect of his presidency, while Netanyahu's refusal to agree to further troop withdrawals was seen as a major challenge to the peace process. The visit also highlighted the tensions between the two leaders, with Netanyahu expressing disappointment at Clinton's decision to visit the Palestinian airport in Gaza. Overall, the visit marked a significant moment in the peace process, but it also highlighted the complexities and challenges that remained to be addressed. In the end, the visit was a crucial step towards a peaceful resolution, but it also underscored the need for continued dialogue and cooperation between Israelis and Palestinians.

topic: Provide a report on the launch and initial assembly of the International Space Station. Include information on the modules involved, the spacecraft used, the launch dates, the assembly process, and the estimated time and resources needed to complete the space station.
questions: What was the job of the astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour?
What was the result of the astronauts' use of the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm?
How many components will make up the completed International Space Station?
What was the mass and length of the space station when the two modules were joined?

How many launches does NASA estimate will be required to completely assemble the space station?
What is the estimated number of spacewalks needed to assemble the space station?
How many astronauts can the completed space station house?
What is the purpose of the space station?
Why did Russia and NASA decide against orbiting the space station closer to MIR?
What was the name of the U.S. module carried into space by the shuttle Endeavour?
What was the name of the Russian control module cylinder?
How long will the assembly of the space station take?
report: After discarding a suggested change of orbit, the Russian Space Agency went ahead with plans to launch its Zarya module of the international space station on Nov. 20, 1998. Although delayed for a day, U.S. plans to launch the space shuttle Endeavour carrying the U.S. module Unity and six astronauts were carried out on Dec. 4. The astronauts' job was to connect Unity with the already-orbiting Zarya as the first step in assembling 100 major components of the planned space station. Using the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm, the two modules were joined setting the stage for a spacewalk by two astronauts the next day to attach electrical connectors and cables. The International Space Station when completed will have a million pound mass and be longer than a football field. It will house up to seven space explorers. The initial assembly of space station components involves linking the US Unity, carried into space by the shuttle Endeavour, with the Russian Zarya. The Russians had asked for a different launch profile in order to be able to transfer equipment from its MIR station, but that was not possible. Endeavour astronauts successfully completed the complicated maneuvers to join the two space objects. NASA estimates that 43 more launches will be required to completely assemble the 16-nation space station. On Friday the shuttle Endeavor carried six astronauts into orbit to start building an international space station. The launch occurred after Russia and U.S. officials agreed not to delay the flight in order to orbit closer to MIR, and after a last-minute alarm forced a postponement. On Sunday astronauts joining the Russian-made Zarya control module cylinder with the American-made module to form a 70,000 pounds mass 77 feet long. NASA estimates 43 more launches and 159 more space walks are needed to assemble the complex. When completed the 16-nation space station will be longer than a football field. It will be used to study adaptation to space flight. Russia and NASA jointly decided against a Russian cost-cutting proposal to orbit the 2nd space station, a 16-country cooperative project, closer to Mir, citing complexity, risk, and bad sun angles. After 5 years of assembly, the research station will house 7 people. A 12-day shuttle mission will attach the US Unity module to the Russian Zarya, already in orbit. Thursday's launch was delayed by a pressure drop. A 2nd attempt Friday was perfect. Unity was attached to Zarya in a blind docking using cameras and computer images. Electrical and cable connections come next. Unity will serve as a passageway for future modules. Two Zarya antennas failed to deploy.
response:
The International Space Station (ISS) was launched and assembled through a series of complex and coordinated efforts involving multiple space agencies and spacecraft. On November 20, 1998, the Russian-built Zarya control module was launched aboard the Russian spacecraft Proton, marking the first stage of the ISS assembly process. The Zarya module was then captured by the space shuttle Endeavour's robotic arm, and attached to the Unity chamber, the first American-made module of the ISS. This historic connection was a significant milestone in the construction of the ISS, marking the beginning of a long-term partnership between NASA and the Russian Space Agency. The Endeavour's mission was a crucial step towards the completion of the orbiting complex, and the astronauts' work paved the way for future crews to continue the assembly process. The successful docking of the Zarya and Unity modules set the stage for a spacewalk by two astronauts to attach electrical connectors and cables between the two components. The ISS will eventually be assembled through 43 more launches and 159 more spacewalks, and will have a mass of 1 million pounds, be longer than a football field, and house up to seven astronauts and cosmonauts. The estimated time and resources needed to complete the ISS are substantial, with NASA estimating that the entire project will require 15 years or more to complete. The Endeavour's 12-day flight included three spacewalks to install handrails and other tools for future crews, marking an important step towards the completion of the space station. The ISS will be a testament to international cooperation and collaboration, and will provide a unique opportunity for scientists and researchers to conduct experiments and research in microgravity. The assembly process was a complex and challenging task, requiring the coordination of multiple space agencies and spacecraft, but the successful launch and initial assembly of the ISS marked the beginning of a new era in space exploration. response:
The state of human rights in China remains a pressing concern, particularly with regards to the treatment of dissidents and political activists. As highlighted in context, the sentencing of three prominent dissidents, Xu Wenli, Wang Youcai, and Qin Yongming, to long jail sentences in 1994 raised questions about the effectiveness of the administration's policy of engaging China in hopes of democratic reform. The harsh prison terms were met with international condemnation, with the U.S. government and exiled dissidents calling for their immediate release. This incident was part of a larger crackdown on dissent, which saw at least 32 dissidents arrested or interrogated in the past three weeks.

The Chinese government's actions have been widely criticized by human rights groups, who view them as manipulative and cynical. For instance, the release of labor rights campaigner Liu Nianchun from prison ahead of Xu Wenli's trial was seen as an attempt to deflect international criticism. Similarly, the detention of Qin Yongmin, a prominent human rights campaigner, hours before China was expected to sign a key U.N. human rights treaty, was a clear indication of the government's disregard for human rights.

The international community has responded to China's human rights record with a mix of criticism and diplomatic engagement. The U.S. government has consistently condemned China's human rights abuses, while also maintaining diplomatic ties with the country. In contrast, some countries have been more willing to engage with China, despite its human rights record. The impact of China's international agreements and obligations on its human rights record is also a subject of debate. While China has ratified several key human rights treaties, its implementation of these agreements has been inconsistent, and it has often been accused of using them as a pretext for further repression.

In conclusion, the state of human rights in China remains a pressing concern, with the treatment of dissidents and political activists being a particular area of concern. The Chinese government's actions have been widely criticized, and the international community has responded with a mix of criticism and diplomatic engagement. The impact of China's international agreements and obligations on its human rights record is a subject of ongoing debate.

Osama bin Laden, the mastermind of the bombings and U.S. cruise missile attack against a supposed terrorist camp in Afghanistan shortly after the bombings was an attempt not only to disrupt the terrorist network but to get bin Laden himself. response:
The US government's actions following the August 1998 bombings of the US embassies in East Africa were swift and decisive. The US launched a missile attack on suspected terrorist camps in eastern Afghanistan on August 20, killing 26 people, in retaliation for the bombings. This move was seen as a pretext for the US to launch another missile attack on Afghanistan, according to the Taliban's chief justice, Justice Noor Mohammed Saqib. The US government also initiated an investigation into the bombings, which led to the identification of a key informant, CS-1, who had been working closely with Osama bin Laden from 1989 to 1996. CS-1 provided crucial information to federal investigators, including details about bin Laden's involvement in deadly attacks on US soldiers in Somalia and elsewhere. The informant's testimony was instrumental in securing the extradition of two associates of bin Laden who were under arrest in Germany and Britain. The US government also took steps to prevent further terrorist attacks, including the arrest of individuals suspected of being part of bin Laden's network in Albania. The Albanian intelligence service, Shik, uncovered a terrorist network operated by bin Laden, which had sent units to fight in Kosovo. The US government also requested the extradition of Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, a top lieutenant of bin Laden, from Germany. US prosecutors requested a 20-day extension to provide Germany with the necessary paperwork to extradite Salim. The evidence showed that Salih Idris, the owner of Al Shifa pharmaceutical plant, had financial dealings with members of Islamic Jihad, an Egypt-based group responsible for the assassination of President Anwar Sadat in 1981. This year's budget discussions also have been hampered because it is the first time since budget procedures were established in 1974 that there has been a surplus, preventing agreement on a budget resolution. Whether to use the 1st surplus in decades for a tax cut, to pay off the national debt, or for new initiatives made the 1998 federal budget negotiations chaotic. The Oct 1 start of the fiscal year was extended 5 times. Major issues were census statistical sampling, federal health plan coverage of contraceptives regardless of religious affiliation, and school aid decisions by the federal gov't or local jurisdictions. Other issues included a Federal Election Commission provision, a road through an Alaskan wildlife refuge, and an airline peanut ban. Committees crafted the budget document after broad agreement was reached when 8 bills were lumped together. In 1998, for the first time in decades, the US budget negotiators faced a surplus. Controversial issues included health insurance paying for contraception, control of new education allocations, an Alaskan wilderness road, whether the 2000 census would include statistical sampling, and establishing an emergency fund. Conservatives felt the results favored the liberals, but both sides were satisfied and glad to finish before Election Day and avoid a government shutdown. After several deadline extensions, Congressional leaders and the White House agreed on an omnibus spending package, the final portion of the $1.7 trillion budget. To offset the new spending, the surplus will be tapped for $20 billion, to the ire of conservatives. This year, without the common goal of reducing the deficit, reaching agreement was very difficult. The United Nations has been actively involved in persuading Libya to extradite the two suspects in the Pan Am 103 bombing case to stand trial in Scotland. The efforts of the UN have been ongoing since 1992, when the UN Security Council imposed sanctions on Libya to force Gadhafi to surrender the two Libyans wanted in the 1988 bombing. The sanctions, which include a ban on direct flights to and from the country, have been in place for over two decades and have had a significant impact on Libya's economy.

The UN has proposed a compromise, under which the suspects would be tried in the Netherlands, with the possibility of serving their sentence in Dutch or Libyan prisons. The stalemate has continued, with the UN sanctions remaining in place and the suspects remaining in Libya. The impact of the sanctions has been significant, with Libya struggling to cope with the loss of air travel and arms sales. The sanctions have also frozen some Libyan assets abroad, further exacerbating the country's economic woes.

In conclusion, the efforts of the UN to persuade Libya to extradite the two suspects in the Pan Am 103 bombing case have been ongoing for over two decades, with little progress made. report: Budget negotiations between the White House and House Republicans were delayed on several issues. At issue were provisions that included requiring Federal Health Insurance providers to provide contraceptives to women as Well as a provision to build a road across a wildlife preserve in Alaska. The contraceptive issue faced an uncertain future while Clinton likely will veto the road. There is disagreement also on how to spend the funding on education. This year's budget discussions also have been hampered because it is the first time since budget procedures were established in 1974 that there has been a surplus, preventing agreement on a budget resolution. Whether to use the 1st surplus in decades for a tax cut, to pay off the national debt, or for new initiatives made the 1998 federal budget negotiations chaotic. The Oct 1 start of the fiscal year was extended 5 times. Major issues were census statistical sampling, federal health plan coverage of contraceptives regardless of religious affiliation, and school aid decisions by the federal gov't or local jurisdictions. Other issues included a Federal Election Commission provision, a road through an Alaskan wildlife refuge, and an airline peanut ban. Committees crafted the budget document after broad agreement was reached when 8 bills were lumped together. In 1998, for the first time in decades, the US budget negotiators faced a surplus. Both sides said this was harder than a deficit situation, but they finally spent $1.7 trillion. The last seven spending bills were the most difficult and finally were merged into one package. Controversial issues included health insurance paying for contraception, control of new education allocations, an Alaskan wilderness road, whether the 2000 census would include statistical sampling, and establishing an emergency fund. Conservatives felt the results favored the liberals, but both sides were satisfied and glad to finish before Election Day and avoid a government shutdown. After several deadline extensions, Congressional leaders and the White House agreed on an omnibus spending package, the final portion of the $1.7 trillion budget. It includes more money for education and defense, business tax breaks, and farm aid, as well as funds for Colombia to use in drug interdiction. To offset the new spending, the surplus will be tapped for $20 billion, to the ire of conservatives. This year, without the common goal of reducing the deficit, reaching agreement was very difficult. Using the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm, the two modules were joined setting the stage for a spacewalk by two astronauts the next day to attach electrical connectors and cables. On Sunday astronauts joining the Russian-made Zarya control module cylinder with the American-made module to form a 70,000 pounds mass 77 feet long. Russia and NASA jointly decided against a Russian cost-cutting proposal to orbit the 2nd space station, a 16-country cooperative project, closer to Mir, citing complexity, risk, and bad sun angles. NASA estimates 43 more launches and 159 more spacewalks will be needed after this mission to assemble the entire orbiting complex. The successful docking of Zarya and Unity demonstrates the capabilities of the shuttle's robot arm and the precision of the astronauts, paving the way for future construction and assembly of the space station. The opening ceremony of the games was held on Sunday night, and it was attended by Thailand's king, Bhumibol Adulyadej. The ceremony began with a torch relay led by Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai, followed by a three-hour show featuring 7,614 performers, with a theme of "Friendship Beyond Frontiers".
